Description: This virtual tour tells the history of the Yolo Basin Foundation and the geography of the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area.
Description 2: Scroll through the multimedia narrative and explore the accomanying map layers, or use the buttons above to jump to a particular chapter. You can also zoom in and out on the map using the +/- controls, and click to zoom/pan.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: The Central Valley, California's agricultural heartland, is an 18,000-square-mile sedimentary valley, fed by vast watershed of the Sacramento and San Joaquin Rivers.
Description 2: The valley's drainage area extends to the crests of the Sierra Nevada and the coast range, a catchment for rain and snowmelt that encompasses 60,000 square miles. Water from the Sacramento and San Joaquin Rivers and their tributaries converge at the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta—a highly modified landscape of tidal sloughs and canals surrounding levee-protected agricultural lowlands—before flowing out to sea via the San Francisco Bay.
Map Credit: Geospatial data sources: USGS NHD+, California Natural Resources Agency.

Description: Located in the northern Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta, the Yolo Basin is a vast, low-lying historic wetland area, filled by distributary streams from the west and Sacramento River overflow to the east.
Map Credit: Early 1900s USGS topographic maps (1:32000 and 1:64000 scale). 32k mosaic basemap layer published by California Department of Fish & Wildlife.

Description: One of the Basin's major western tributaries is Putah Creek, whose water historically spread out and infiltrated into the soil at the Putah Creek Sinks.
Media Credit: Putah Creek Sinks, 1950, showing Cowell Ranch and Glide Ranch in background.
Map Credit: Early 1900s USGS topographic maps (1:32000 and 1:64000 scale). 32k mosaic basemap layer published by California Department of Fish & Wildlife.

Description: The Central Valley was once a complex mosaic of grasslands and riparian forests, transitioning to freshwater wetlands and tidal channels at the Delta.
Description 2: The riparian forests lining rivers like the Sacramento and tributary streams like Putah and Cache Creeks had lush canopies of valley oak, sycamore, and cottonwood. Along the edges of the valley were foothills of valley oak savanna (roblar).
Media Credit: 1852 lithographs of the Sacramento River by William H. Dougal. Source: David Rumsey Map Collection.
Map Credit: Central Valley data from Central Valley Historic Mapping Project via DataBasin. Fine-scale mapping via San Francisco Estuary Institute (SFEI) Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta Historical Ecology Study. Categories are combined and adjusted for presentation.

Description: The Yolo Basin was covered in freshwater emergent tule wetland (or tulare in early Californian Spanish), flanked by seasonal wet meadows.
Description 2: At the Putah Creek sinks, el Río de los Putos branched out in distributary channels as it passed through a vast willow thicket (sausal). The San Francisco Estuary Institute (SFEI) reconstructed these historical ecological boundaries based on 18th to 19th century expedition reports and survey maps.
Media Credit: Laying tules in preparation for burning. Source: Sacramento Archives & Museum Collection Center via Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area Land Management Plan.
Map Credit: Central Valley data from Central Valley Historic Mapping Project via DataBasin. Fine-scale mapping via San Francisco Estuary Institute (SFEI) Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta Historical Ecology Study. Categories are combined and adjusted for presentation.

Description: The Patwin people are the indigenous inhabitants of the southwestern drainage of the Sacramento River.
Description 2:
Patwin people lived in villages throughout the Yolo Basin and Sacramento River Valley, located on local high ground such as natural river levees and knolls, and benefited from the rich floodplains for fishing Chinook salmon, hunting deer and elk, and gathering tule reeds to weave into homes and baskets.

Starting in the 1800s, the Patwin were forcibly removed from their villages and hunting lands through successive waves of colonization: from the Spanish mission project, in which Patwin villages were raided for laborers, slaves, and converts; to an epidemic of malaria introduced by European trappers in the river valley; to the claims and appropriation of indigenous land for the Spanish land grants followed by the Gold Rush; to the ultimate relocation of remaining Patwin to federally created rancherías or reservations.

Today’s surviving Patwin communities include the Yocha Dehe Wintun Nation, who are now based along Cache Creek in the Capay Valley of eastern Yolo County, having reclaimed the fertile lowland river corridor after being relocated to the dry upper reaches of the valley in Rumsey. The term Patwin, or Wintun Tʼewe, refers more precisely to the language traditionally spoken in this region. While the local Southern dialect of Patwin (spoken in what is now central Yolo County from Putah Creek to Suisun Bay) became extinct after contact with Spanish settlers, the Patwin language is undergoing a revival and being taught again in tribal schools.
Map Credit: Present-day Indian Lands and Native Entities published by CA Governor's Office of Emergency Services. Historic Native American Territories in California published by University of Redlands. Patwin place names from Napa Valley Historical Society as published by Noahedits on Wikimedia Commons. Historic delta waters from San Francisco Estuary Institute (SFEI) Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta Historical Ecology Study and sacramentoriver.org GIS library. Other geospatial data: USGS NHD+, California Natural Resources Agency.

Description: Euro-American settlement began with the Mexican land grant ranchos, then expanded as the Delta's fertile soil attracted farmers and ranchers during the Gold Rush period.
Description 2: The natural levees on the banks of the Sacramento River supported settlements and farms, including the growing city of Sacramento (formerly known as New Helvetia).
Media Credit: Land grant boundary map of Laguna de Santos Callé showing Putah Creek, the Putah Creek Sinks, and the tulares. Source: Online Archive of California
Map Credit: Map of the Valley of the Sacramento including the Gold Region (1848) retrieved from David Rumsey Map Collection.

Description: Beginning with the Swamp Land Act of 1850, earthen flood control levees and irrigation canals were constructed to support Delta farming by 'reclaiming' seasonal wetlands like the Yolo Basin.
Description 2: Settlements in the Sacramento Valley continued to grow, vulnerable to rising river levels from winter storms and spring snowmelt that culminated in the destructive flood of 1862.
Media Credit: Lithograph of K Street in the city of Sacramento, California, during the Great Flood of 1862. Source: Online Archive of California
Map Credit: State Engineer's Map of Northern California (1884) retrieved from David Rumsey Map Collection.

Description: In 1917, the US Congress authorized the Sacramento River Flood Control Project, a system of levees and weirs that direct flood waters away from developed areas and into the designated undeveloped Sutter and Yolo bypasses.
Media Credit: Animated overview of the Sacramento River Flood Control System produced by the US Army Corps of Engineers
Map Credit: Geospatial data sources: USGS NHD+, California Natural Resources Agency, SACOG.

Description: The 92-square-mile Yolo Bypass begins at Fremont Weir near Knights Landing, along the Sacramento River and extends south to the Delta. The Fremont Weir is located just below the junction of the Feather River and Sacramento Rivers.
Description 2:
The Fremont Weir is a 2 mile wide low concrete structure where Sacramento River flood water flows into the Yolo Bypass. When river stage exceeds 32 feet,Sacramento River flood waters flow over the Fremont moving south while also rising from the east side toe drain and expanding westward. Fully inundated, the Yolo Bypass becomes a vast "inland sea," conveying flood waters from eastside and westside sources across the Yolo Basin floodplain, re-entering the Sacramento River near Prospect and Liberty Islands.

The California Department of Water Resources can manually open and close the Sacramento Weir located on the eastside of the Bypass near I-80 bridge over the Sacramento River near West Sacramento. DWR staff remove boards on the Sacramento Weir to let in additional water from the Sacramento and American Rivers. This water flows west through the Sacramento Bypass and meets up with the Yolo Bypass.

The Bypass also receives periodic inflow from Cache Creek, Knights Landing Ridge Cut, Willow Slough and Willow Slough Bypass. Putah Creek provides a perennial inflow into the east side toe drain. During flood events these westside tributaries provide fast rising, uncontrolled flood waters into the Bypass. Uncontrolled westside flood flows can occur before, during or after the Fremont Weir spills.
Map Credit: Geospatial data sources: USGS NHD+, California Natural Resources Agency, SACOG.

Description: The different sources of water are visible in this aerial photograph from the March-April 2011 storm, owing to the varying sediment loads in the Sacramento River versus the tributary streams.
Map Credit: Aerial photo mosaic from the March-April 2011 flood event, showing visible sediment plumes corresponding to flows from the four major tributaries of the Yolo Bypass. Source: USGS High Resolution Orthoimagery (201104_sacramento_ca_0x3000m_utm_clr)

Description: Before the Yolo Causeway was built, there was no year-round route across the wetlands.
Description 2: A series of seasonal roads including the Tule Jack Road led through the tulares, as seen in this Gold Rush era map, but winter travelers had to venture across the flooded tule marshes by ferryboat, a dangerous crossing during high waters. To facilitate crossing the Yolo Bypass and expand commerce between Sacramento and the San Francisco Bay Area, the Yolo Causeway was built around the same time as the flood control project, in 1917.
Map Credit: Gold And Quicksilver District Of California (1848) retrieved from David Rumsey Historical Map Collection.

Description: One of the early settlers of the Yolo Basin was J.H. Glide, who purchased a large area in the 1870s that would eventually become much of the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area.
Description 2: The Glide family reclaimed the wetlands of the Putah Creek Sinks, turning thousands of acres into dry grazing land, and built a large and successful cattle and sheep business.
Map Credit: Official Map of Yolo County, California. Compiled from Official Records by C.C. Stitt, County Surveyor, 1939 retrieved from David Rumsey Historical Map Collection.

Description: The Yolo Bypass is an important stop along the Pacific Flyway, a north-south migratory pathway along which millions of birds travel each year. Sacramento Valley wetlands provide critical overwintering habitat for waterfowl, shorebirds, songbirds, and raptors that then return to the various points west and north including the Canadian Arctic for the summer.
Description 2: The lines on this map are GPS tracks of migratory ducks and geese collected by the USGS Dixon Field Station.
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: Over time, more and more wetland habitat in the Yolo Basin, the Delta and the greater Sacramento Valley was drained and converted to agricultural and urban land….
Map Credit: 1937 aerial photography for the Sacramento/San Joaquin Delta. Source: basemap layer published by California Department of Fish & Wildlife.

Description: By the 1990s, almost no remnant wetland habitat remained in the Yolo Basin.
Map Credit: 1993 aerial photography (USGS Digital Ortho Quads)

Chapter: Founding YBF and the Wildlife Area
Description: The origin story of the Yolo Basin Foundation and the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area is a story of partnerships. Creating, protecting, and managing these thousands of acres of wetland habitat required cooperation between local, state and federal agencies and private landowners, hunters and birdwatchers, farmers, and conservation organizations.
The story begins as a community effort, born at kitchen tables in Davis.
Description 2:
The original maps for a proposed wildlife area were drawn by two members of Yolo Audubon, Steve Chainey and Ted Beedy. They invited others to discuss their concept. The next step was to build support for the proposal, including presenting slide shows at the City of Davis Vets Memorial.

Building off the success of the Putah Creek Council in advocating for adequate flows for fish habitat during an ongoing drought in the early 1990s, members of the Council organized the Yolo Bypass Working Group to explore the concept of recreating wetlands at the Putah Creek Sinks, the creek's downstream destination.

Description: Recognizing that most of the potential land for a wetland restoration was privately owned, the Putah Creek Council decided to work with—instead of in opposition to—local landowners.
Description 2: In February 1990, the Yolo Basin Working Group sponsored a meeting with area landowners and the California Department of Fish and Game, at the California Trucking Association Building in West Sacramento, to discuss the proposal for a Yolo Basin Wildlife Area. At that meeting, Department of Fish and Game Region 2 Director Jim Messersmith committed to working with the community on creation of a wildlife area at the Putah Creek Sinks, if it could be determined that an adequate water supply existed to manage wetlands.

Description: Later the same month, the Yolo Basin Foundation was officially founded to advocate for and coordinate the creation of a new State-owned and managed wildlife area which ultimately became the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area. The founding board meeting was held at the kitchen table of Robin Kulakow and Bill Julian.
Media Credit: Left to right: Ted Beedy, Steve Chainey, Robin Kulakow, Paul Simons, Susan Sanders, Bill Julian, Manny Carbahal

Description: Yolo Basin Foundation board members and friends sought the support of elected officials who would become critical advocates of the project's success, including Congressman Vic Fazio, Yolo County Supervisors Betsy Marchand and Helen Thomson, and City Councilwoman Lois Wolk.

Thanks to the wide-ranging collaboration and advocacy efforts, in December 1991, the California Wildlife Conservation Board completed the purchase of 3100-acres of fallow row crop land—a portion of the Cowell Ranch then owned by Prudential Life Insurance—for $4.57 in funds from Proposition 70 and the State General Fund. The first milestone, land, was reached successfully.
Map Credit: 1993 aerial photography (USGS Digital Ortho Quads)

Description: In 1991, Richard Harris, then District Director for Congressman Vic Fazio met with Robin Kulakow and Bill Julian at their home in Davis.
Description 2: Fazio was interested in the wetlands project. They discussed various ways in which the Congressman could support it. A few weeks later, Harris came back with news about a new program that was recently funded for the US Army Corps of Engineers (Corps) to do habitat restoration in areas that were destroyed by existing Corps projects. This program became known as Section 1135: Under the authority provided by Section 1135 of the Water Resources Development Act of 1986, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers may plan, design and build modifications to existing USACE projects, or areas degraded by USACE projects, to restore aquatic habitat for fish and wildlife.

Description: First, the Yolo Basin Foundation obtained letters of support from Davis City Council, Yolo County Board of Supervisors, the State Assembly and State Senate.
Description 2: Congressman Fazio then worked to get Congressional authorization and appropriation of funds for the Corps to begin the environmental documentation, state and federal permitting and engineering for the restoration of the Yolo Basin Wetlands (Section 1135 project).

Description: On 13 February 1992, Congressman Fazio, US Army Corps of Engineers and other project members held an event on the east levee of the Yolo Bypass to celebrate the purchase of property for the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area and the initiation of the Yolo Basin Wetlands Project. Later that day, a reception was held at UC Davis to honor Ted Beedy and Steve Chainey for their vision of restoring wetlands at the Putah Creek Sinks
Description 2: Then, activity picked up on making the restoration vision a reality. In April 1992 the Final Environmental Assessment/Project Modification Report for Yolo Basin Wetlands project was released by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. In January 1993 Assistant Secretary of the Army gave his approval for US Army Corps staff to initiate plans and specifications for the Yolo Basin Wetlands project. On September 10, 1993 the Project Cooperation Agreement, a contract between US Army Corps of Engineers and State Fish & Game regarding cost sharing and post restoration maintenance. That November, the resource inventory of the Putah Creek Sinks, titled Suitability Analysis for Enhancing Wildlife Habitat in the Yolo Basin, was completed by Jones & Stokes Associates under contract with the Central Valley Habitat Joint Venture.
Media Credit: Celebrating the purchase of the first 3700 acres: Dave Paullin, Steve Chainey, Ted Beedy.
Map Credit: 1993 aerial photography (USGS Digital Ortho Quads)

Description: The wetland restoration design took shape over the next two years. Initial concept plans envisioned a mosaic of north-south oriented seasonal and permanent wetlands across the Cowell Ranch.
Description 2: State Fish and Game, Region 2 staff including Paul Hoffmann worked tirelessly with Corps staff to design the wetlands, roads, and water control structures on the recently purchased property. Governor Wilson. Signed State Senate Bill 494, sponsored by Assemblyman Tom Hannigan, which directed Caltrans to transfer the 400 acres between I-80 and the railroad tracks to Fish and Game. In April 1994 the Causeway property was transferred from Caltrans to Fish and Game for inclusion in the Yolo Basin Wetlands Project.

Description: At the same time, 180 acres of additional property was purchased by the Wildlife Conservation Board for Department of Fish and Game to provide an entrance to the new Wildlife Area and expand habitat land to the north of I-80.
Description 2: Thirteen acres were also purchased outside the Bypass for the Wildlife Area Headquarters.
Map Credit: 1993 aerial photography (USGS Digital Ortho Quads)

Description: The Yolo Basin Wetlands Project also included a stormwater and wastewater treatment wetland for the City of Davis. The Davis Wetlands eventually became a separate Section 1135 project.
Media Credit: Congressman Vic Fazio on an early field trip to the site of the Davis Wetlands

Description: Over the next several years, the Yolo Basin Working Group brought together many different agencies and organizations to address agency and community concerns and to develop a management plan.
Description 2: Dave Paullin, the executive director of the Central Valley Habitat Joint Venture, working with Robin Kulakow, the new Yolo Basin Foundation executive director, served as the coordinators  for the Working Group meetings from 1991-1997.  Each issue was worked through over a  number of years with multiple agencies in small group meetings. The following agencies and organizations were involved:  The State was represented by Dept. of Fish and Game (now the Department of Fish and Wildlife), The Wildlife Conservation Board, Dept. of Water Resources, and he Reclamation Board (now the Central Valley Flood Protection Board). Federal interests included US Fish and Wildlife. And the Sacramento District Corps of Engineers.  Local Districts were there too includingSacramento-Yolo Mosquito and Vector Control District, and Yolo Resource Conservation District and Reclamation District 2068. Elected officials from Davis and Yolo County, as well as staff participated.  Conservation organizations included: The Nature Conservancy, Ducks Unlimited, California Waterfowl, Yolo Audubon, Yolano chapter of Sierra Club. Yolo County Farm Bureau and farmers in the project vicinity also attended the Working Group meetings. Sacramento International Airport staff attended.

Description: The Working Group met monthly to discuss many issues including the effect of creating and managing habitat in the Yolo Bypass, a key component of the Sacramento River Flood Control System. The effect of increased wetland vegetation on movement of flood waters and the need to maintain a clear floodway was of paramount concern.
Description 2: Restoration of wetlands in a flood control area was a new concept. Growth of emergent and riparian vegetation were seen as slowing down flood flows. Slower moving flood flows could mean prolonged flooding upstream. The Corps did extensive hydraulic modeling that was used to inform the shape, size and direction of the proposed wetland ponds. The percent of emergent vegetation cover (tules and cattails) was limited by pond. Planting of riparian vegetation (trees and brush) was severely limited. There was also concern that an increased presence of endangered species, including Swainson's hawks and giant garter snakes, would compromise the flood control agencies’ ability to maintain the floodway.

Description: Meanwhile, Yolo Basin Foundation was busy building community support for the establishment of the new wildlife area through monthly field trips to other wetlands restoration sites and to the recently purchased property.
Description 2: The first Bucks for Ducks fundraiser was held in 1991 at the home of John and Judy Whitcombe, benefitting the wetlands project through an auction of wildlife art. For many years, Yolo Basin Foundation volunteers gave slideshows about the wildlife area concept to Yolo County business organizations and others, including updates to state and local agencies.

Description: California Duck Days, a community based  wetlands and wildlife festival, held February 1994, was the first of many family and educational activities centered around the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area.

In the 1990s, wetland restoration projects were less widespread and best practices not yet defined. Management of the future wetlands was a great concern for the Sacramento/Yolo Mosquito and Vector Control District.
Description 2:
Many people were concerned with the potential increase in mosquitoes in Davis and the Pocket Area of Sacramento, increasing the risk of mosquito-borne diseases. Landowners were concerned that traditional farming practices would not be tolerated near a wildlife area and their livelihood would be adversely affected.

The California Department of Fish and Game and Yolo Basin Foundation worked with District leadership to design a mosquito management regime that included the use of steep slopes on ponds edges, management of vegetation and specifically timed wetland flood up and draw down. These discussions were the early development of the Mosquito Control Best Management Practices used today in managed wetlands in Northern California.

Description: In January 1994 the State Reclamation Board gave final approval of a unique Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) on Threatened and Endangered Species.
Description 2:
This agreement was facilitated and drafted by Foundation board members and finalized by State Fish and Game attorneys. It outlines a set of actions that address the concerns of state and federal flood control agencies and state and federal wildlife management agencies. The signing of this MOU represented a model of interagency cooperation that has guided other habitat restoration efforts. An agreement recognizing that flood control was the primary management goal in the Yolo Bypass was also drafted.

Representatives of The Reclamation Board, State Department of Water Resources, State Department of Fish and Game, US Fish and Wildlife Service, and the US Army Corps of Engineers signed the MOU and the Management Agreement at a special ceremony arranged by Congressman Vic Fazio in February 1994 at the West Sacramento Port headquarters.

Description: By 1995, the designs and plans for the wetland restoration had taken shape, and construction was ready to begin! The Corps and Department of Fish and Game brought in Ducks Unlimited to manage the final design and construction of the wetlands.
Over 150 people attended the groundbreaking ceremony in front of the ready to plant riparian area adjacent to the westside levee on 17 August 1995.
Description 2:
Speakers included master of ceremonies, Supervisor Betsy Marchand, Secretary of the Interior Bruce Babbitt, Congressman Vic Fazio, Brig. General Bruce Scott, Corps, Colonel John Reese, Corps, Michael Spear, Regional Director USFWS, Robin Kulakow, Yolo Basin Foundation, Douglas Wheeler, Secretary of California Resources Agency, Jim Sarro, Wildlife Conservation Board, and Dr. Alan Wentz, Ducks Unlimited. Yolo Basin Foundation received the Dept. of the Interior National Wetlands Conservation Award for the private sector, from Western Region, USFWS.

Brig General Bruce Scott, the Commanding officer of the Southern Pacific Region of the Army Corps of Engineers said that “the Yolo Basin Wetlands Project is, next to the restoration of the Florida Everglades, the largest project in the US.” Secretary Babbitt described the commonality with the massive Everglades restoration: “the role of partnerships; the central place of imagination; and the indispensable contributions of an individual. Cooperation among private and public entities and interests, among national, state and local governments, where narrow interests are set aside in favor of a common goal characterizes both the Yolo Basin and the Everglades project."

"We are working with landscape”, Babbitt suggested. “The imagination to see in a landscape not a series of isolated, separate uses, but a harmonious blending of agriculture, urbanism and wildness, is particularly striking in the Yolo Basin Project.”

Description: By November 1995, after months of grading and earthwork, the first phase of construction was completed, with 800 acres of new wetland ponds.
Description 2: The next month, during the Sacramento Audubon Christmas bird count, the first flock of Northern pintails was observed alighting over the new ponds. Construction on the remaining wetlands continued over the next two years. A 28 acre riparian woodland was planted with native tree seedlings. Several grassland areas were seeded with native grass seed.
Map Credit: 2002 aerial photography. Source: USGS

Description: In Summer and Fall 1997, the Yolo Basin Wetlands Project finished with the construction of approximately 2300 acres of seasonal wetlands, 185 acres of semi-permanent wetlands, 28 acres of riparian woodland and 480 acres of grassland/upland.  Construction also included many miles of gravel access roads and several thousand water control structures..
Description 2: The Yolo Basin Wetlands Project was the first Section 1135 project completed by the Corps. It was the largest wetlands restoration effort underway in the Western US under the North American Waterfowl Management Act. The NAWMP is an agreement between the US, Canada, and Mexico that recognizes that the recovery and perpetuation of waterfowl and other migratory birds depends on restoring wetlands and associated ecosystems through the North American continent.
Map Credit: 2002 aerial photography. Source: USGS

Description: In Summer 1997, with the wetlands construction almost completed, Yolo Basin Foundation held the first Discover the Flyway Teachers Workshop, titled Reading, Writing and Wildlife. The teacher workshops continue to this day. Over 1500 teachers have attended workshops prior to bringing their students to participate in a Discover the Flyway field trip.
Description 2:
Education is at the heart of the Foundation’s mission, and in June 1997 the Yolo Basin Foundation signed a Memorandum of Understanding with California Fish and Game recognizing their long-term partnership to provide public outreach and educational programs for the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area.

The same summer, the Fish and Game Operations and Maintenance Facility (Headquarters) was completed and Fish and Game staff moved in.

Description: On 15 November 1997, the Wildlife Area reached the national spotlight with a dedication ceremony and opening celebration attended by President Clinton and 800 community  supporters. The ceremony marked the transfer of the Wildlife Area from the US Army Corps of Engineers, who oversaw the design and construction of the project, to the California Department of Fish and Game, who would manage it going forward.
Description 2: In addition to the President, speakers at the ceremony at Parking Lot C included Congressman Vic Fazio, John Garamendi, Assistant Deputy Director of US Dept. of the Interior, John Zhirsky, Assistant Secretary of Civil Works for US Army Corps of Engineers, Doug Wheeler, Secretary of State Resources Agency, Richard Rominger, Assistant Secretary of US Dept. of Agriculture.

Description: Yolo Basin Foundation's Robin Kulakow, Congressman Vic Fazio, Department of Interior Deputy Secretary John Garamendi and adjacent landowner and farmer Greg Schmid led President Clinton on a rainy walk along a road adjacent to the seasonal wetland ponds.
Description 2: Right on cue, a flock of Northern pintail flushed from the pond in a spectacular demonstration of the promise of the new wetlands.

Description: In 1998, Yolo Basin Foundation volunteers worked with Dept. of Fish and Game to construct the 3 acre Yolo Demonstration Wetlands at the Headquarters.
Description 2: A grant from the US Fish and Wildlife Partners for Wildlife program and one from the US Bureau of Reclamation Wetlands program provided funding for design, earthmoving, irrigation supplies and planting equipment. The Corps provided the riparian plants. On a very hot weekend in August 1998 a Davis Boy Scout Troop  installed drip irrigation and planted 400 young trees, shrubs and grasses.   The coordination of volunteers during the weekend was the culmination of an eagle scout project.  Soon after the wetlands were flooded up for the first time in August 1998.  The Demonstration Wetlands would soon become the core of the Foundation's Discover the Flyway science and social studies program for regional K-12 students.

Description: Later that year Yolo Basin Foundation opened a program office in the Headquarters alongside Dept. of Fish and Game staff.  Yolo Basin Foundation launched the ongoing Flyway Nights lecture series just after moving to the new Headquarters.
In Spring 1998 the completion of the City of Davis Wetlands was celebrated.
Description 2: The wetlands later opened to the public in Winter 2000. Yolo Basin Foundation volunteers continue to lead monthly field trips in partnership with the City of Davis.

Description: Over the ensuing years, the Yolo Basin Foundation continued to grow its community footprint through the Discover the Flyway educational program, and continued to build partnerships with public agencies, land owners, and water users.

The Foundation continued to facilitate the Yolo Bypass Working Group, which it founded in 1998 to discuss agriculture, habitat, and water management issues among the many stakeholders with an interest in the Bypass.
Description 2: Participants include local, state and federal agencies and districts, elected officials, farmers, landowners, wildlife conservation groups, researchers and others with an interest in land management issues in the Bypass. Issues of interest include flood protection, wetland management, agriculture, water quality, wildlife and fisheries, and recreation and education. The Yolo Bypass Management Strategy: A Framework for the Future was the first deliverable for the group. The Working Group met regularly through 2020 (1999-2020 meeting summaries are published online). The Yolo Bypass Working Group received the 2000 Governor’s Environmental and Economic Leadership Award.

Description: The Yolo Basin Foundation has earned a reputation for collaboration with diverse public and private partners to further issues of mutual concern. Over the years it has gained the trust of the local farmers, duck club owners (privately owned and managed wetland property owners), elected officials, scientists and agency staff.
Description 2: The success of the Working Group led to Yolo Basin Foundation being asked to coordinate stakeholder involvement for many studies and plans funded by Yolo County, Sacramento Area Flood Control Agency, Dept. of Fish and Wildlife, Department of Water Resources, US Army Corps and the US Geological Service. Yolo Basin Foundation was the project grant manager for the study, Methylmercury, and Other Constituents in Sediment and Water from Seasonal and Permanent Wetlands in the Cache Creek Settling Basin and Yolo Bypass, Yolo County, California, 2005−06.

Description: In Winter 1999, the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area was declared a Globally Important Bird Area. The goal of the program is to identify sites in each state that are essential for sustaining naturally occurring populations of bird species and to protect or manage those sites for their long-term conservation.
Description 2: Designation of the Wildlife Area at the Global level is the highest level of recognition. The official designation states: “This site provides habitat for globally significant numbers of waterfowl, continentally significant numbers of Least Sandpiper and Northern Pintail and nationally significant numbers of Canvasback, Dunlin and American White Pelicans.”

Description: In the spring of 1999, the Yolo Basin Foundation moved from Robin Kulakow’s home office to a newly purchased modular office unit located at the Wildlife Area Headquarters.
Description 2: The Flyway Nights lecture series was launched that same year. The Nature Bowl Semi-finals were located at the Wildlife Area for the first time for area schools. Yolo Basin Foundation’s volunteer corps continued to grow with multiple training sessions each year.

Description: In 1999, the Wildlife Area was renamed in honor of Congressman Vic Fazio Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area. The Wildlife Area is an ongoing legacy of Congressman Vic Fazio’s vision and support for wetland restoration.  The Congressman passed away in 2022.

By 1999, 2,000 K-12 students and their parents had visited the Wildlife Area on Discover the Flyway field trips. Thousands of people had driven the Auto Tour loop to view wildlife. Yolo Basin Foundation had a volunteer corps of over 100. The Fish and Wildlife Area hunting program was underway with growing popularity. In 2000, Discover the Flyway served a record 1500 students.
Plein air artists flock to the Wildlife Area to capture the beauty of the wetland landscape...
...and show their work at the Art of the Bypass show and silent auction at the annual Bucks for Ducks fundraiser.

Beginning in 2004, people began to notice a sunset flyout of bats from under the Yolo Causeway. By 2005, In response to growing interest in the bat colony, Yolo Basin Foundation began the Bat Talk and Walk program to educate visitors about the growing colony of Mexican Free-tailed bats spending the summer roosting in the expansion joints of the Causeway.
Media Credit: Bats roosting in the Yolo Causeway expansion joints

Description: December 2001 saw a huge expansion of the Wildlife Area with the purchase of 12,000 additional acres of ranch land for the Wildlife Area.  The new size was 16,800 acres.
Description 2:
The Glide Causeway Ranch, Giverson Ranch and Tule Ranch properties, along with the Los Rios Farms properties along Putah Creek, expanded the Wildlife Area to a total of 16,800 acres. This same year, the new Yolo Bypass Management Strategy was published by the Yolo Bypass Working Group after two years of meetings between land owners, water users, and public agencies. Work began on the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area Land Management Plan to include the additional 12,000 acres.

Dept. of Fish and Game Region 2 Director, Banky Curtis, made made a commitment to the Yolo County Board of Supervisors to maintain all existing agricultural leases on these lands until a management plan was complete and land use changes initiated. Wildlife friendly farming and ranching continued. Rice fields in the Northeast Unit were experimentally flooded in July to provide shallow water and mudflat habitat for migrating shorebirds. This experiment became the 200 acre shorebird management requirement of the rice lease on the Wildlife Area and a state-wide model for a Farm Bill incentive program.

Description: In 2002-2003, while the Land Management Plan was being updated to include the expanded acreage, habitat improvements to existing seasonal wetlands began.
Description 2:
These wetlands were originally restored in 1994. By 2002, the science of wetlands restoration had evolved, including the widespread use of GPS systems for surveying elevations. It was now possible to have thousands of elevation points rather than hundreds from traditional surveying methods. This allowed for the addition of shallow benches and ridges, meandering channels, islands and scattered deep areas. Microhabitats were created by the changes in water depth as a result of the swales, islands, deep areas, and low ridges created by earthmovers. The diversity of the wetland habitat improved significantly.

The improvements included new water distribution systems and rebuilt pumps. This meant better water management to control vegetation for flood protection, wildlife food production and the ability to move water quickly for mosquito control. Ducks Unlimited and California Waterfowl received grants from North American Wetlands Conservation Act and State Duck Stamps to do this work.
Map Credit: 2005 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos. Source: USGS

Description: More improvements came to the Wildlife Area’s existing wetlands as additional federal funding was received in 2005-2006. This resulted in more  acres of improved wetlands with a wide spectrum of microhabitats.
Map Credit: 2009 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos. Source: USGS

Description: Construction of two brood ponds adjacent to I-80 began in 2007, totalling 280 acres.
Description 2: Water management of brood ponds includes continuous flooding through early summer for use by ducklings and other waterbirds. The new brood ponds were integral to  improvements of the water delivery system for the rice fields
Media Credit: Sep 2009 (Paul J Hames / CA DWR)
Map Credit: 2009 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos. Source: USGS

Description: Restoration was completed in 2010 on a stunning 4500 acres of new wetlands on the Glide Tule Ranch, purchased by Fish and Game in 2001.
Description 2: These include traditional managed wetlands, brood ponds, ephemeral basins, ancient slough restoration and tidal wetlands.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos. Source: USGS

Description: The extension of the Auto Tour Route opened in 2011 to take visitors through active rice fields.
Description 2:
If you visit in the spring you see busy farm equipment getting the soil ready for flood up and aerial seeding. In the summer you drive by lush, green rice fields with scattered waterbirds. In the fall you see rice harvesters hard at work with a parade of waterbirds following behind, feasting on disturbed insects and other invertebrates. In the winter, the harvested fields are flooded for rice decomposition. The flooded fields attract thousands of birds that come to eat the leftover rice that provides carbohydrates and protein from the invertebrate soup.

The original 28-acres of riparian woodland planted in 1995 some of the original trees grew into large cottonwood, Oregon ash and willow trees. Many of the trees are brush like, having survived many generations of beaver activity. The native grass seed planted in 1995 and 1996 mostly washed away or drowned during a series of mid-1990s flood events. Several acres of meadow barley did survive the flooding and can be seen south of parking lot E.
Media Credit: Photo credit: Yvonne Hunter
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos. Source: USGS

Description: The continuing story of the Yolo Basin, and the progress to date, would not be possible without the extraordinary, expansive network of colleagues, friends, and volunteers.

As ecosystems change, water supply fluctuates, and new scientific knowledge develops, the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area must be actively managed to balance the parallel goals of flood protection, agriculture, wildlife conservation, recreation and education in the face of a changing climate. Adapting to shifting conditions requires continued partnerships between agencies and land owners.
Description 2: In this section, we will learn about the mosaic of different land uses in the Wildlife Area, and the way they change seasonally throughout the year. This map outlines the fields and ponds that make up the Wildlife Area, colored by their uses. The Wildlife Area spans 16,800 acres including about 6,000 acres of wetlands.
Media Credit: Sunrise over seasonal wetlands © Skyler Lewis

Description: The Yolo Bypass provides flood protection for hundreds of thousands of people and billions of dollars of housing and infrastructure.  Flood protection comes first in the Yolo Bypass.
Description 2:
Habitat restoration projects must all be flood neutral, meaning vegetation must not slow down flood waters. Roads and internal levees must remain under 3 feet. All improvements require approval of the Flood Protection Board. It takes active management by Fish and Wildlife field personnel based on an annual plan to maintain the area to meet flood protection goals.

In spring 2011, when this aerial photo was taken, inundation of the Yolo Bypass began in March. Flood waters of 100,000 cubic feet per second moved through the Bypass.
Map Credit: Aerial photo mosaic from the March-April 2011 flood event, showing visible sediment plumes corresponding to flows from the four major tributaries of the Yolo Bypass. Source: USGS High Resolution Orthoimagery (201104_sacramento_ca_0x3000m_utm_clr)

Description: Semi-permanent ponds, 4 to 5 feet deep, are filled with water year-round except when drained for vegetation removal or infrastructure improvements.
Description 2:
These ponds provide year-round habitat for the area's resident waterfowl and wading birds, including those that nest in the Wildlife Area during the spring and summer: including American coots, mallards, gadwall, cinnamon teal, and ruddy ducks. Pelicans can be seen fishing in these ponds.

Green's Lake in the northeast is a remnant oxbow lake that dates back to the pre-development Sacramento River Valley. It provides habitat while serving as a holding basin for rice irrigation.
Media Credit: Sep 2009 (Paul J Hames / CA DWR)

Description: Seasonal wetlands are shallower, 6-18 inches deep. These ponds, planted with tule and cattail, are flooded beginning in October. They begin to dry out between February and April.
Description 2: Seasonal wetlands are flooded beginning in October to provide wintering habitat for large numbers of migratory waterfowl and shorebirds.  The start of flood up is determined by the Sacramento-Yolo Mosquito and Vector Control District based on daily sampling of mosquito larvae.
Media Credit: Seasonal wetlands along the auto loop © Skyler Lewis

Description: Beginning around March 15, these seasonal ponds are no longer flooded and drained.
Description 2: As they begin to dry out and the  soil warms up, wetland plants including swamp timothy, water grass and others sprout.  The seeds of these plants will provide protein rich nutrition for migratory waterfowl that arrive from late August through November.  Timely draining of seasonal wetlands occurs between  February and April before invasive weeds can establish. They are mowed and disced on a 3 to 5 year rotation. If water is available, the seasonal wetlands can be irrigated once to encourage growth of beneficial wetland plants. Some wetlands are first partially drained to provide shallow spring shorebird habitat.

Description: Wetland-associated grasslands provide cover for ground nesting birds. Limited riparian habitat lines some of the ditches, providing habitat for songbirds and raptors as well as nesting habitat for resident birds.
Media Credit: Upland habitat from the Tule Trail © Skyler Lewis

Description: Putah Creek flows into the Wildlife Area from the west, carrying water from Lake Berryessa and downstream tributaries.
Description 2:
The Creek eventually flows into the east-side Toe Drain that runs alongside the levee of the Sacramento Deep Water Ship Canal, and out to the Sacramento River flowing through the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta near Liberty Island.

The Toe Drain is subject to tidal action as it is directly connected to the Delta. Flap gates at the Lisbon Weir catch water moving north during the high tide. This water creates a reservoir upstream of the weir that is pumped through canals on the Wildlife Area for flooding of rice and wetlands and irrigation of pasture.

Description: Stretches of riparian woodland and scrub line water bodies including Putah Creek and Green's Lake.
Description 2: Trees such as cottonwood, willow, and oregon ash support land mammals and nesting birds of prey.

Description: CA Dept. of Fish and Wildlife receives revenue from two grazing leases and a rice lease on the Wildlife Area.
Description 2: The revenue from these five-year leases provides a substantial portion of the operations budget for management of the Wildlife Area.  The leases require wildlife friendly rice cultivation and grazing practices.  The Yolo County Resource Conservation District receives payment from Fish and Wildlife to manage the leases.

Description: Alongside dedicated wetlands, the Wildlife Area supports a total of 2,400 acres of rice cultivation. The rice ground is located on the former Glide Causeway Ranch.
Description 2: Rice is planted in May-June and harvested in September. This collaboration between local rice growers and Fish and Wildlife helps with land management costs and creates bird friendly habitat.  A mixture of short grain rice and wild rice is grown. Wild rice, actually a grass, is grown in rotation with the rice. Wild rice has a 90-day growing season, shorter than that of the rice. Rice harvested on the Wildlife Area has been sold for sushi in Japan and Korea and for brewing beer at the Fairfield Budweiser plant.

Description: After the harvest, usually starting in November, the rice fields are flooded to provide additional acres of wetland habitat for migratory waterfowl and shorebirds.
Description 2: Fields are eventually drained the next March as migratory waterfowl and shorebirds begin to head north, to prepare for the next season's harvest.

Description: Rice farmers are required by their lease to set aside 200 acres of fallow fields for summertime shorebird habitat.
Description 2:
These areas (which change year to year) are flooded in succession in July and August to provide the shallow water foraging habitat preferred by migrating shorebirds traveling south from northern breeding grounds. This migration begins in July and continues through the fall.

Rice farming in the Yolo Bypass presents challenges due to unplanned flood events that can delay field preparation in the spring.. Rice planted in late spring can mean a late harvest that is still going on when early rains come. Wild rice with its shorter growing season is well-suited to the flood risk that Bypass farmers face.

Description: About 5,000 acres of irrigated and dryland pasture supports a cattle lease on the Glide Ranch portion of the Wildlife Area. There is also a lease on several hundred acres between the railroad tracks and I-80.  Wildlife friendly grazing practices provide upland habitat alongside grazing range.
Description 2: For several years there was a row crop lease on the Wildlife Area.  That lease was not renewed and the area is now in irrigated pasture. The Dept. of Fish and Wildlife staff seed small areas in safflower, corn and milo as a food and cover crop for pheasants.
Media Credit: Snow geese with cattle in the Causeway Ranch unit (photo courtesy Dave Feliz)

Description: The grasslands of the Tule Ranch section of the Wildlife Area include rare vernal pool and playa pool formations—ephemeral wetlands formed in shallow depressions that fill throughout the rainy season.
Description 2:
As they dry in the spring, characteristic rings of wildflowers form along the receding shoreline in response to changing soil moisture. Flowers include goldfields, miniature lupine, butter-and-eggs, downingia, monkey flower, and tidy tips. These pools contain a high diversity of plant species including some that are endangered. Several species of fairy shrimp live in the pools including the endangered Conservancy and Tadpole Fairy Shrimp.

Grazing is key to the survival of the plants native to the vernal pools. Without grazing, invasive rye grass will overtake the native plants. Collaboration between Fish and Wildlife and the ranch managers is key to the survival of this increasingly rare habitat.

For a thorough look at the wide variety of wildflowers visible at the Tule Ranch, see Charlie Russell’s photographs with identification.
Media Credit: Vernal pools and the umbrella barn at Glide Tule Ranch © Skyler Lewis

Description: The Yolo Bypass is a landscape in flux.
Description 2: The Yolo Basin Foundation and its partners continue to work together to keep improving ecological function and meeting the needs of the Bypass's array of users and inhabitants as habitat needs evolve and climate changes.
Media Credit: Management of seasonal wetland, adjusting the water level by adding boards or taking them away.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: The Los Rios check dam on Putah Creek is an important feature of the Wildlife Area and adjacent agricultural water delivery system. Careful management is required to balance the hydrologic benefits of the Los Rios Check Dam to the farmers and wetland managers with the migratory needs of  the adult salmon trying to reach spawning gravels upstream..
Description 2:
Along with the Lisbon Weir and Road 106A crossing, the Los Rios Check Dam is a partial barrier to salmonid migration between Lake Solano on Putah Creek and the Bay-Delta estuary.

On 20 November, 1999, the Los Rios check dam boards were removed for the first time specifically for fall-run Chinook salmon migration up the creek. An adult salmon was spotted almost immediately starting the journey up Putah Creek to spawning gravels upstream. The restoration of salmon habitat on Putah Creek that began in 2000 continues to this day. The continuing partnership between Dept. Fish and Wildlife, Solano County Water Agency, Putah Creek Council, Yolo Basin Foundation and adjacent farmers continue to ensure the proper timing of flows to attract fall-run salmon. Discussions are underway to build a short channel for up-migrating salmon to bypass the Los Rios check dam.

The Yolo Bypass Drainage and Water Infrastructure Improvement Study (2014) and the Study Update (2020) outline drainage network improvements throughout the Yolo Bypass including the Wildlife Area. Improvements include new control structures, higher-capacity canals, and new bridge crossings.

Description: Future restoration projects in the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area will work to restore wetland, riparian, floodplain, and tidal marsh habitats while benefiting migrating salmon.
Description 2: The Lower Putah Creek Realignment Project is currently under development. A new naturalized channel for Lower Putah Creek, with seasonally inundated floodplain wetlands and riparian habitat, would connect to the Toe Drain through a 90-acre restored freshwater tidal marsh. The proposed route bypasses the Los Rios Check Dam and Lisbon Weir for more direct adult fish passage from the Bay-Delta estuary 23 miles of upstream spawning habitat that terminates at the Putah Diversion Dam at Lake Solano.

Description: An array of restoration projects are already underway throughout the greater Yolo Bypass, promising expanded floodplain habitat for fall-run salmon as well endangered winter- and spring-run salmon and green sturgeon.
Description 2:
The Big Notch, formally known as the Yolo Bypass Salmonid Habitat Restoration and Fish Passage Project, is under construction at the Fremont Weir. This new operable gate will connect the Sacramento River to the Tule Canal through an operable gate in the Fremont Weir. The lower gate elevation will increase water flows into the Bypass. Juvenile Chinook salmon will benefit from larger and longer-lived food-rich floodplain rearing habitat.

Adult fall-run and endangered, winter and spring-run Chinook salmon and green sturgeon will face fewer delays when returning to their upstream spawning grounds, both from the Big Notch and from the concurrent Fremont Weir Adult Fish Passage Project.

Description: Ongoing partnerships between the Yolo Basin Foundation, Yolo County, Dept. of Fish and Wildlife and Dept of Water Resources, Ducks Unlimited, and Metropolitan Water District are working to address flooding impacts to Yolo Bypass agriculture and wetlands caused by the anticipated increase in frequency and duration of flows due to operation the Big Notch project.
Description 2: The Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area Habitat & Drainage Improvement Project is led by Ducks Unlimited and supported by a coalition of partners, including California Department of Fish and Wildlife (CDFW), Yolo County, Yolo Basin Foundation, and the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California. Identified as the top priority in Yolo County’s 2014 Yolo Bypass Drainage & Water Infrastructure Improvement Study, the project includes five major components to enhance management of wetland resources and agricultural operations. Project improvements will allow the CDFW to: add 220 acres of managed wetlands, increase the productivity of existing wetlands, improve wildlife-friendly management of rice fields, reduce on-site flooding from the South Davis Drain, increase and improve public access and maintenance. This project is funded with grants from the Delta Conservancy, State Dept of Fish and Game, and State Duck Stamps.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: Finally, additional restoration work is underway in the greater Yolo Bypass, including the Lower Elkhorn setback levee, an expanded Sacramento Weir and floodplain restoration in the Sacramento Bypass; a new fish rescue facility at the Wallace Weir; and a fish-friendly reconfiguration of the Wildlife Area’s adjacent Lisbon Weir.
Media Credit: Lisbon Weir

Description: Beyond flood protection, wetland habitat, and agriculture, the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area benefits the regional community with an array of recreation and education opportunities.
Description 2: In the next section, learn more about the opportunities awaiting visitors to the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area today.
Media Credit: Yolo Basin Foundation volunteer and retired State Fish and Wildlife Deputy Director, Rob Floerke, leads a field trip for a local school in 1995, before the Discover the Flyway program was started.

Description: The Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area is located off Interstate 80 between Davis and Sacramento.
Description 2: Take exit 78 from I-80 to visit the wildlife area (just east of the exit) and the headquarters (2 miles west on Chiles Rd).
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: Take advantage of the popular auto tour loop for year-round wildlife viewing that passes through permanent ponds, seasonal wetlands, and rice fields.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: Several hiking trails are accessible year round.
Description 2: Get out of the car at Parking Lot C and walk the loop along the Tule Trail to see seasonal wetlands to the west and permanent ponds to the east.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: In the late fall and winter, the Wildlife Area is a hunting destination.
Description 2: Duck hunting season begins in October and extends through January, while pheasant season begins mid-November. The hunting area begins at a check-point and is separate from the year-round public wildlife viewing zone. Wildlife viewers are kept at a safe distance from hunting activity.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: Outside of hunting season, expanded public access begins in February. Catch the tail end of the migratory waterfowl season, and the bountiful shorebird display in the spring.
Description 2: These trails are open until hunting begins again in October.
Media Credit: Greens Lake, August 2016 © Joy Elson
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: The Yolo Basin Foundation's outdoor education program, Discover the Flyway, hosted 60,000 K-12 students in its first decade (1997-2017).
Description 2: Teachers participate in a workshop prior to bringing their class out for the first time.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: The Yolo Demonstration Wetlands located at the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area headquarters  serve as the starting point for Discover the Flyway classes.
Description 2: Students participate in activity stations based on their grade level.  Afterwards the students visit the larger Wildlife Area for a guided field trip.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: In a series of tours each summer, Yolo Basin Foundation-sponsored Bat Talk and Walks take thousands of visitors to see the largest urban colony of Mexican free-tailed bats in California.
Description 2: The migratory bats roost in the expansion joints under the Yolo Causeway, and at sunset fly out in a spectacular cloud to feed.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: In the spring, Yolo Basin Foundation staff and volunteers lead guided wildflower tours of the vernal pools at Glide Tule Ranch and Grasslands Regional Park.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: The successful education and outreach programs that Yolo Basin Foundation began in the 1990s continue to serve thousands of people every year. There are many ways for people of all ages to learn about and visit the Wildlife Area.
Description 2: Ongoing programs include California Duck Days; Discover the Flyway; Wetlands Wagon, in class visits by staff and volunteers; Wetlands Kits for classrooms;  Summer Day Camps; Bat Talk and Walk;, Explorer series events; monthly field trips to the Wildlife Area and the City of Davis Wetlands;, Flyway Nights lecture series;  and a monthly newsletter.
Media Credit: The California Duck Days festival over the years

Description: The Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area hosts a diverse range of bird species that vary from season to season: ducks and geese that migrate long distances to the bypass in the winter, spring shorebirds foraging in shallow wetlands, summer nesting waterfowl and year-round residents, blackbirds flocking among tule reeds, and birds of prey hunting overhead.
Media Credit: The Yolo Basin Foundation published these western waterfowl identification cards, drawn by Keith Hansen and showing dabbling ducks followed by diving ducks, in 1992.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: This section describes some of the common birds seen at the Wildlife Area, and the habitats and seasons in which they are often found.
Description 2: For a full list, take a look at the bird observations on eBird. As you read this section, roll over bird names for links to species information and charts of seasonality specific to the Yolo Bypass. Illustrations courtesy of the John James Audubon Center at Mill Grove, Montgomery County Audubon Collection, and Zebra Publishing.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: Spectacular numbers of wintering waterfowl come to the Wildlife Area starting in October.
Description 2: The most common duck visitors are the northern pintail and the northern shoveler, but also look for the American widgeon, green-winged teal, canvasback, common goldeneye, and bufflehead. Pintails arrive as early as August, but most birds start arriving in October, peaking in December. They head north again come March and April.
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: Wintering geese and swans tend to arrive in November, with over 10,000 snow geese and greater white-fronted geese visiting each season.
Description 2: White-fronted geese include the Pacific and Tule subspecies, each arriving from different northern nesting grounds. Ross's geese, and tundra swans also visit. Geese arrive from as far north as Banks Island in the Arctic Archipelago and Wrangel Island off the north coast of Russia.
Media Credit: Aerial footage filmed and edited by Eric Holmes of the UC Davis Center for Watershed Sciences.
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: Other waterbirds stay closer to home.
Description 2: Birds like the coot, mallard, gadwall, and cinnamon teal—along with some shovelers— nest at the Wildlife Area during the summer. Look for broods of ducklings on the brood ponds and semi-permanent ponds in May through July.
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: Dabbling ducks spend their time feeding  and resting in the shallow seasonal ponds and flooded rice fields.
Description 2: Dabbling ducks include mallard, northern shoveler, cinnamon and green-winged teal, American widgeon, and northern pintail.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: Diving ducks can be seen in the semi-permanent ponds and in the deeper areas of seasonal ponds.
Description 2: Diving ducks include goldeneye, canvasback, and ruddy ducks.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: Geese and swans spend their winters in the Wildlife Area's flooded rice fields and grasslands
Description 2: Overwintering anserids (geese and swans) include greater white-fronted geese (which include the tule geese subspecies) , snow geese and the closely-related Ross's geese, and tundra swans.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: Great blue herons, great egrets, snowy egrets, American bitterns, and black-crowned night herons can be found fishing and wading year-round in shallow ponds and among tules and cattails.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: Some shorebirds (including avocets, black-necked stilts and killdeer) nest in the Wildlife Area in April, with chicks appearing in May.
Description 2:
Other shorebirds (including black-bellied plovers, greater yellowlegs, long-billed curlew, dunlin, and long-billed dowitchers) head north in April to nest, returning to the Wildlife Area mid-summer.

Still others (phalaropes, willets, godwits, and some sandpipers) use the Wildlife Area as a stop on their migration to their northern summer breeding grounds, visiting in both the spring and late fall.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: Waders like the white-faced ibis nest in tule clumps over the summer and forage in the rice fields and seasonal wetlands all year.
Media Credit: White-faced ibis foraging in the designated shorebird pond on flooded rice fields
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: White pelicans and double-crested cormorants can be seen throughout the year fishing in deeper waters.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: Look among the tangle of tule and cattails for red-winged and Brewer's blackbirds and marsh wren...
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: ...and in the waters below the tule for rails like the gallinule, Virginia rail and sora foraging at the base of the tules and cattails.
American coots and pied-billed grebes, both agile swimmers, browse the deeper waters of semi-permanent ponds and seasonal wetlands.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: The grassland ecosystems host western meadowlark, yellow-billed magpie, and horned larks.
Description 2: Associated upland habitat hosts white-crowned, golden-crowned, savannah and lark sparrows, among others.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: Birds of prey include the red-tailed hawk, Swainson's hawk, and northern harrier.
Description 2:
Swainson's hawks arrive from Mexico and South America in April to nest, staying through September (highlighted map areas indicate designated Swainson Hawk foraging ground), while other raptors can be spotted year-round.

...and check the trees for great horned owls!
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: In 2014, birds and other wildlife of the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area inspired over 50 professional and amateur artists to create a beautiful  mural on the Education trailer at the Yolo Demonstration Wetlands. This community based volunteer labor of love expresses appreciation for the beauty of the creatures and plants that inhabit the Wildlife Area.
What makes the Vic Fazio Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area so special?
Description 2:
It is the location on the Pacific Flyway in view of the State Capitol, a wild place in an urban setting.

It is the wildlife: over 200 species of birds, the chance to see beavers, otters, mink, snakes, and butterflies.

It is the thousands of bats flying out from under the Yolo Causeway every summer evening.

It is the Fish and Wildlife staff who manage the area in the heat, the cold and in the wind. It is the farmers and ranchers who are willing to try new approaches.

It is the Yolo Basin Foundation staff and the hundreds of dedicated volunteers who make school field trips possible. They spend their weekends working behind the scenes at California Ducks Days, sitting at an information table at Parking Lot A, or leading field trips so that new people can enjoy the wetlands. They serve food at Bucks for Ducks and stuff envelopes with invitations. The list goes on and on.

It is the visitors that make this place special: the teachers, the parents, the thousands of students who visit every year, many of them experiencing nature for the first time.

It is the birders and other wildlife viewers, the hikers, painters, photographers, anglers, hunters, people of all walks of life and all ages taking time out of their busy lives to spend time in a peaceful place.

It is a community story–

Over 30 years ago a small group of people came together with an idea: to recreate the wetlands of the Putah Creek Sinks. They had their training as ecologists, a map and the energy to act on a vision of a future landscape. What started as a local project has taken on national or even international stature.

The effort to create the Wildlife Area is the story of a community working together. That community is an element of the partnerships that made this place possible. It is more than the logos on a big sign on I-80. The community is a continuously growing group of visitors, colleagues and friends who love this place.

The Wildlife Area is a wonderful place for birds and people. It is also a vision for the future: the successful co-existence of agriculture, flood protection, wildlife habitat, recreation and education in a growing metropolis.

—Robin Kulakow, August 2022

This story map was produced by Skyler Lewis.

Funding was provided by a grant from Yolo Basin Foundation.

Thank you to all of the photographers who donated their work to this project. All photos not in the public domain are owned by the photographers credited or by Yolo Basin Foundation.
